The rule will take effect on October 3, 2025, unless significant adverse comments are received by August 14, 2025, which would prompt a withdrawal and further review.
events.title: FCC Removes Obsolete Regulations
events.why_relevant: This action reflects the FCC's efforts to modernize regulatory frameworks, potentially impacting telecommunications policy and industry practices.

events.summary: The Trump administration delayed the implementation of a Biden-era rule that would have restricted Medicare coverage for certain expensive skin substitute products lacking scientific backing. This delay, announced by the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) on April 11, 2025, allows companies like Extremity Care LLC to continue billing Medicare for their high-cost products. The delay follows a $5 million donation from Extremity Care to Trump's Super PAC, MAGA Inc., on February 24, 2025. The Biden rule aimed to reduce Medicare spending on ineffective products, which surged to over $10 billion in 2024.
events.title: Trump Administration Delays Medicare Rule on Skin Substitutes

events.summary: On July 14, 2025, the Trump administration proposed a new Medicare rule for skin substitutes, capping payments at $806 per square inch but not restricting coverage to scientifically proven products. Despite opposition from the MASS Coalition, the new rule would allow continued reimbursement for high-cost, unproven products. events.summary: On August 5, 2025, the FBI released a comprehensive report indicating that crime in the United States significantly decreased in 2024, reaching its lowest levels since the 1960s. The report highlighted a substantial drop in both violent and property crimes across all categories and population groups. Specifically, the violent crime rate fell to 349 per 100,000 people, and the property crime rate dropped to 1,760 per 100,000 people. The murder rate also saw a historic decline of 14.9%, marking the fastest drop ever recorded. Despite these findings, major media outlets have largely underreported the data.

events.summary: An appeals court vacated a district judge's finding of contempt against the Trump administration regarding the deportation of Venezuelans to an El Salvador prison without due process. The decision from a divided three-judge panel overturned Judge James Boasberg's April ruling, which accused the administration of violating a March order to halt deportations. Judges Gregory Katsas and Neomi Rao, both Trump appointees, supported the majority opinion, while Judge Cornelia Pillard dissented. The ruling has been celebrated by the US attorney general as a victory for the administration's use of the Alien Enemies Act.

events.summary: The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) issued a final rule amending Parts 8, 20, and 51 of its regulations to align with court decisions. This action removes obsolete rules and updates the Code of Federal Regulations to reflect current legal standards, following the Ohio Telecom and Iowa Utilities Board II decisions. The changes include restoring previous rule texts and removing vacated requirements, effective immediately upon publication.
events.title: FCC Amends Internet and Telecommunications Rules
events.why_relevant: This rule ensures that FCC regulations accurately reflect current legal standards, removing outdated provisions and enhancing regulatory clarity.

events.summary: Con Edison, New York City's monopoly utility, disconnected over 88,000 households in the first half of 2025 as it seeks an 11% increase in utility bills. The disconnections affected nearly 2.5% of Con Edison's customers, with many households remaining without power for extended periods. The utility's actions have drawn criticism from city and state politicians, who argue that the disconnections are inhumane, especially during extreme weather conditions.
